title: It‚Äôs easy making green: Muppets continue to make a profit 50 years into their run
content: A variety show that‚Äôs still revered for its absurdist, slapstick humor debuted 50 years ago. It starred an irreverent band of characters made of foam and fleece. Long after ‚Äú The Muppet Show ‚Äù‚Äòs original 120-episode run ended in 1981, the legend and legacy of Miss Piggy, Fozzie Bear, Gonzo and other creations concocted by puppeteer and TV producer Jim Henson have kept on growing. title: As Syria‚Äôs new government consolidates its power, the Kurdish minority fears for its future
content: Renewed fighting in Syria in recent weeks between government-aligned forces and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) isn‚Äôt just a local issue. It has serious implications for the stability of the rest of the Middle East. Syrian government forces launched an offensive in early January into areas of northeastern Syria controlled by Kurdish forces. The operation enabled the government to gain control of key oil and gas fields and major border crossings with Iraq and Turkey. Of particular ...

title: Xi Jinping has dismissed two of China‚Äôs most senior generals. What does this mean?
content: Last weekend, China‚Äôs Ministry of National Defence announced that the country‚Äôs two most senior generals ‚Äì Zhang Youxia and Liu Zhenli ‚Äì would be removed from office and placed under investigation for serious disciplinary violations. Zhang had been the People‚Äôs Liberation Army‚Äôs most senior general since October 2022. He was the highest ranking military member of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China (CCP), the party-state‚Äôs 24-member executive policy-making body. Zhang was also the seni...

title: Great white sharks grow a whole new kind of tooth for slicing bone as they age
content: Ken Bondy/iNaturalist , CC BY-NC A great white shark is a masterwork of evolutionary engineering. These beautiful predators glide effortlessly through the water, each slow, deliberate sweep of the powerful tail driving a body specialised for stealth, speed and efficiency. From above, its dark back blends into the deep blue water, while from below its pale belly disappears into the sunlit surface. In an instant, the calm glide explodes into an attack, accelerating to more than 60 kilometres per h...

title: New fear unlocked: runaway black holes
content: A runaway black hole leaving a streak of new stars in its wake. James Webb Space Telescope / van Dokkum et al. Last year, astronomers were fascinated by a runaway asteroid passing through our Solar System from somewhere far beyond. It was moving at around 68 kilometres per second, just over double Earth‚Äôs speed around the Sun. Imagine if it had been something much bigger and faster: a black hole travelling at more like 3,000km per second. We wouldn‚Äôt see it coming until its intense gravitational...

content: People walk along a street in Nuuk, the capital of Greenland. content: A US view of the cold war world, 1950, showing the fearsome power of the USSR. Cornell University ‚Äì PJ Mode Collection of Persuasive Cartography. Major magazines such as Time, Life and Fortune commissioned a generation of famous cartographers ‚Äì who had come of age in the second world war ‚Äì to explain the new geopolitics to a mass audience that was highly engaged after the catastrophic global conflict they had just li...

title: Afcon drama: what went wrong and what went right at the continent‚Äôs biggest football cup in Morocco
content: The 35th edition of the Africa Cup of Nations, hosted by Morocco, produced thrills and several story lines, some good and others not so good. It ended in a victory for Senegal ‚Äì their second Afcon championship. While the 1-0 victory over Morocco was deserved, the championship game ended on a sour note as fans invaded the field and the winning country abandoned the game for 16 minutes. I‚Äôm a sports communications scholar and an author of multiple books on football as it relates to Africa. The top...

title: 5 years on from the junta‚Äôs coup, Myanmar‚Äôs flawed elections can‚Äôt unite a country at risk of breaking apart
content: Five years ago, on February 1 2021, Myanmar‚Äôs top generals decapitated the elected government. Democratic leaders were arrested, pushed underground or forced into exile. Since then, the economy has spluttered and foreign investors have headed for the exit. The only growth industries ‚Äì mostly scam centres , drugs and other criminal activities ‚Äì enrich those already well-fed. The military junta has kept its stranglehold via draconian curbs on civil and political liberties. It has bolstered its fig...

title: Why the shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis is so significant ‚Äì expert Q&A
content: Federal immigration agents in the city of Minneapolis are accused of having wrestled a 37-year-old intensive care nurse called Alex Pretti to the ground and then shooting him dead. The killing took place just over a mile from where another American citizen, Renee Good, was allegedly fatally shot by federal agents weeks earlier. The latest incident prompted angry protests from people in Minneapolis who want the immigration enforcement operation in their city to end. We spoke to Mark Shanahan, an ...

title: Iran‚Äôs biggest centres of protest are also experiencing extreme pollution and water shortages
content: Iran‚Äôs current wave of protests is often interpreted as having been sparked by inflation, currency collapse, corruption and repression. These explanations are not wrong, but they are incomplete. Beneath the country‚Äôs political and economic crisis lies a more destabilising force that is still largely missing from international analysis: environmental breakdown. title: One country is trying to outlaw political lying, without curbing free speech
content: Lightspring/Shutterstock For the past two years, the Welsh parliament ‚Äì or Senedd ‚Äì has been grappling with how to tackle deliberate lying by politicians and how to rebuild public trust in democracy. There is broad agreement across parties in Wales that the current system offers few real consequences for dishonesty . As one Senedd member put it: ‚ÄúLying flourishes in politics because we can get away with it‚Äù. That frustration has now translated into legislative action. A bill that would make it i...

content: Reza Pahlavi, Iranian opposition leader and son of the last shah of Iran. content: Donald Trump‚Äôs newly launched ‚ÄúBoard of Peace‚Äù presents itself as a bold attempt to break with what its founders describe as decades of failed international diplomacy. Its charter opens with a declaration that few would openly dispute: ‚ÄúDurable peace requires pragmatic judgment, common-sense solutions, and the courage to depart from approaches and institutions that have too often failed.‚Äù It is true that the world urgently needs to overcome decades of inertia to reform its international organisa...

title: What a US military base lost under Greenland‚Äôs ice sheet reveals about the island‚Äôs real strategic importance
content: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers via Wikimedia Commons In the summer of 1959, a group of American soldiers began carving trenches in the Greenland ice sheet. Those trenches would become the snow-covered tunnels of Camp Century, a secret Arctic research base powered by a nuclear reactor. It was located about 150 miles inland from Thule, now Pituffik, a large American military base set up in north-western Greenland after a military agreement with Denmark during world war two. title: Lebanon‚Äôs orchards have been burnt, wildlife habitat destroyed by Israeli strikes ‚Äì raising troubling international law questions
content: Smoke rises from Israeli airstrikes on southern Lebanese villages on Sept. 23, 2024. AP Photo / Hussein Malla More than a year after a ceasefire nominally ended active fighting, much of southern Lebanon bears the ecological scars of war. Avocado orchards are gone and beehives destroyed . So, too, are the livelihoods they supported. Meanwhile, fields and forests have disappeared under the intense fire caused by white phosphorus shelling . Shrapnel and unexploded bombs , however, remain. Such grim...

title: Humanity‚Äôs oldest known cave art has been discovered in Sulawesi
content: Supplied When we think of the world‚Äôs oldest art, Europe usually comes to mind, with famous cave paintings in France and Spain often seen as evidence this was the birthplace of symbolic human culture. But new evidence from Indonesia dramatically reshapes this picture. Our research, published today in the journal Nature , reveals people living in what is now eastern Indonesia were producing rock art significantly earlier than previously demonstrated. title: Grains of sand prove people ‚Äì not glaciers ‚Äì transported Stonehenge rocks
content: Ask people how Stonehenge was built and you‚Äôll hear stories of sledges, ropes, boats and sheer human determination to haul stones from across Britain to Salisbury Plain, in south-west England. Others might mention giants, wizards, or alien assistance to explain the transport of Stonehenge‚Äôs stones, which come from as far as Wales and Scotland . content: The red-nosed cuxiu is endangered. Cavan-Images/Shutterstock Look down at the rainforest floor. Rotting flowers shift under the assault of tiny petal-eating beetles. content: January arrives with a familiar hangover. Too much food. Too much drink. Too much screen time. title: The way Earth‚Äôs surface moves has a bigger impact on shifting the climate than we knew
content: Our planet has experienced dramatic climate shifts throughout its history, oscillating between freezing ‚Äúicehouse‚Äù periods and warm ‚Äúgreenhouse‚Äù states. Scientists have long linked these climate changes to fluctuations in atmospheric carbon dioxide. However, new research reveals the source of this carbon ‚Äì and the driving forces behind it ‚Äì are far more complex than previously thought. title: When science discourages correction: How publishers profit from mistakes
content: Flawed scientific articles don‚Äôt just clutter journals ‚Äî they misguide policies, waste taxpayer funds, and endanger lives. Errors in top-tier research persist due to a broken correction system. Consider our own recent experiences. In March 2025, Communications Earth & Environment published a paper claiming oil palm certification reduces yields and drives land expansion. title: Most of the world just agreed on something: a new treaty to protect our oceans
content: gabrielvieiracosta/Shutterstock In a moment being celebrated by global marine conservationists, a new UN high seas treaty comes into force on January 17 providing a new way to govern the world‚Äôs oceans. Formally known as the Biodiversity Beyond National Jurisdiction agreement, it will allow for the creation of protected areas in international waters, like national parks. title: Ghana collects half the blood it needs ‚Äì digital approaches can improve that
content: Infinite Photo/Shutterstock.com It is late, the ward is crowded, and the clock is moving faster than everyone would like. A doctor has stabilised the patient as best they can, but one thing is missing ‚Äì blood. A relative is asked to ‚Äútry somewhere else‚Äù, and within minutes, the family is on the phone, calling friends, contacting church groups, posting in WhatsApp chats, hoping that someone nearby is eligible, willing and able to reach the hospital in time. title: Growing up alongside deadly fires inspired me to study them ‚Äì and fight flames with swarms of drones
content: Growing up in Greece, wildfires were a constant presence each summer. In 2007, I remember watching TV footage of fires ravaging the Peloponnese peninsula and island of Evia, destroying forests and homes, taking lives. The sight of helicopters and firefighting aircraft crossing the smoky skies was both terrifying and awe-inspiring. Then when I was 17, flames crept dangerously close to my home in Kavala, northern Greece. I recall standing outside with water-hose in hand, scanning the horizon and h...

title: One uprising, two stories: how each side is trying to frame the uprising in Iran
content: Since the outbreak of the current wave of protests in Iran, two sharply competing narratives have emerged to explain what is unfolding in the streets. For the ruling establishment, the unrest is portrayed as a foreign-engineered plot. They argue it is an externally-driven attempt to destabilise the state through manipulation, infiltration, and psychological operations. title: Does adding ‚Äòplease‚Äô and ‚Äòthank you‚Äô to your ChatGPT prompts really waste energy?
content: Serene Lee/Getty Images Cut the words ‚Äúplease‚Äù and ‚Äúthank you‚Äù from your next ChatGPT query and, if you believe some of the talk online , you might think you are helping save the planet. The idea sounds plausible because AI systems process text incrementally: longer prompts require slightly more computation and therefore use more energy. title: Venezuela, Gaza, Ukraine: is the UN failing?

title: Autocrats have long lists of political enemies. This is how Donald Trump has tried to silence his
content: The list of people Donald Trump has punished or threatened to punish since returning to office is long. It includes the likes of James Comey, Letitia James, John Bolton, as well as members of the opposition, such as Adam Schiff, Mark Kelly and Kamala Harris. In fact, he has gone so far as to call Democrats ‚Äú the enemy from within ‚Äù, saying they are more dangerous than US adversaries like Russia and China. According to Lucan Way, a professor of democracy at the University of Toronto, when a leade...
creator: Justin Bergman, International Affairs Editor, The Conversation

title: China‚Äôs five green economy challenges in 2026
content: As China heads into the new year it will start rolling out its 15th five‚Äëyear plan, this one is for 2026-2030. Beijing is doubling down on greening its economy , and aims to hit two major climate goals: ‚Äúcarbon peaking‚Äù , where carbon dioxide emissions have reached a ceiling by 2030, and ‚Äúcarbon neutrality‚Äù , where net carbon dioxide emissions have been driven down to zero by 2060. Yet, China‚Äôs green push sits uneasily with its energy realities: coal still provides about 51% of its electricity a...
creator: Chee Meng Tan, Assistant Professor of Business Economics, University of Nottingham

title: Brigitte Bardot defined the modern woman and defied social norms
content: Herbert Dorfman/Corbis via Getty Image Brigitte Bardot‚Äôs death, at the age of 91 , brings to a close one of the most extraordinary careers in post-war French cultural life. Best known as an actress, she was also a singer, a fashion icon, an animal rights activist and a symbol of France‚Äôs sexual liberation. Famous enough to be known by her initials, B.B. symbolised a certain vision of French femininity ‚Äì rebellious and sensual, yet vulnerable. Her impact on beauty standards and French national id...
creator: Ben McCann, Associate Professor of French Studies, University of Adelaide

title: Revolutionary rap: Nigerian star Falz has kept protest music alive
content: Nigerian rapper, actor and social media star Falz released his sixth studio album, The Feast , in 2025. Few Nigerian popular musicians have shown as much versatility and staying power as the man behind the #ElloBae and #WehDoneSir social media trends. For over a decade now, Falz has been marrying musical skills and social activism with digital savvy and comedy. His rise to global prominence was solidified with his 2018 song This is Nigeria . But it began in 2014 with Marry Me off his debut album...
creator: Paul Onanuga, Lecturer, Federal University, Oye Ekiti

title: Sudan‚Äôs civil war: A visual guide to the brutal conflict
content: Mahmoud Hjaj/Anadolu Agency via Getty, Ebrahim Hamid, Getty, Hussein Malla/Getty, Anadolu/Getty, The Conversation Sudan‚Äôs brutal civil war has dragged on for more than 2¬Ω years, displacing millions and killing in excess of 150,000 people ‚Äì making it among the most deadly conflicts in the world today.
